Sentencas: This paper reports on the fabrication and performance of solid-oxide fuel cell (SOFC) anodes utilizing yttria reaction-sintered zirconia (YRSZ).
Titulo: Fabrication and evaluation of solid-oxide fuel cell anodes employing reaction-sintered yttria-stabilized zirconia

Sentencas: Through the reaction-sintering process, the technical-grade YSZ commonly used in the Ni-YSZ anode cermet is replaced with lower-cost ZrO2 and Y2O3 materials.
Titulo: Fabrication and evaluation of solid-oxide fuel cell anodes employing reaction-sintered yttria-stabilized zirconia

Sentencas: When sintered in the presence of nickel oxide, ZrO2 and Y2O3 form cubic-phase YSZ at temperatures characteristic of SOFC processing (1400-1550 degrees C).
Titulo: Fabrication and evaluation of solid-oxide fuel cell anodes employing reaction-sintered yttria-stabilized zirconia

Sentencas: Reaction sintering enables the formation of YSZ during cell fabrication, reducing SOFC anode raw-materials cost and the number of SOFC-fabrication processes.
Titulo: Fabrication and evaluation of solid-oxide fuel cell anodes employing reaction-sintered yttria-stabilized zirconia

Sentencas: This paper reports the results of a broad range of characterization and performance measurements to evaluate the YRSZ material, including (I) crystal structure, (2) morphology, (3) pore-size distribution.
Titulo: Fabrication and evaluation of solid-oxide fuel cell anodes employing reaction-sintered yttria-stabilized zirconia

Sentencas: (4) electronic resistivity, (5) fracture strength, (6) gas transport and catalytic activity, and (7) electrochemical performance.
Titulo: Fabrication and evaluation of solid-oxide fuel cell anodes employing reaction-sintered yttria-stabilized zirconia

Sentencas: Material properties and performance are found to be comparable to or better than equivalent materials fabricated by conventional processes.
Titulo: Fabrication and evaluation of solid-oxide fuel cell anodes employing reaction-sintered yttria-stabilized zirconia
Fabrication and evaluation of solid-oxide fuel cell anodes employing reaction-sintered yttria-stabilized zirconia
